bibl.title: Letter fragment from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, August 25, 1889

div1.p: Carter writes that his life has been unsettled for the part ten years and a struggle for the past four or five. He discusses his work of caring for patients in hospitals and aboard vessels.

div1.head: Letter fragment from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, August 25, 1889
div1.p:
Well this is my birthday & exactly
how old I am I do not know - nearly 40 I think-
I cannot but think how unsettled my life has been for the
past ten years, & what a struggle for the past 54 or 6or 5: It
isn't not well to get older & not to feel more self-confidence
or development of mental strength: especially not to feel
more content or settled. However there are many things
“not well”, & god will govern it as seems right - nay as is right.
Ed still requires a good deal of extra care; but we
don't mind that so long as it is successful in keeping
the little fellow from getting sick again.

He takes the greatest interest in the boats & is perfectly
happy when he can go rowing & hang over the side & put
his hand in the water.

We I have had quite a run of vessels recently
the latter part of last week before last & the beginning of last week
were very hard, I had 5 ships in (7800 tons in all) the
largest I have had this season Saturday I went out
at 5. A.M. & got back at 8.30 P.M. coming in once
only after a barrel of sulphur. The danger from Rio is
about past & that from Havana has pretty well begun.
also a good deal of fever on the N. coast of S. America: Cathegena
La Guijra & Boca del Toro. Got in my 1st lot of Chagres
Fever (Panama) last week; 4 cases-all of whom recovered
I have had no man die under my care since I came to Quar-
antine-out of 147 patients in hospital & many light cases
aboard ship - but one man died when I had dysentery last
summer (Aug 26) who I suppose would have died had I
been able to see him, since the failure of the Panama

Canal there are few ships from Colon (Aspin wall) & hence much
less sickness than last year & the work on the Niciragua Canal had
not begun enough to make much shipping- although about
1/2 doz schooners have left Mobile & Pascagoula with lum
ber for Graytown & I suppose I will have an opportunity
to investigate the Central American fevers by the end of Sept-
ember. However a good part - the hardest part of the quar-
antine has passed: everything works smoothly enough now &
there are only 2 to 2 1/2 months more, depending on the fall,
And although the most dangerous time for fever here is from Aug 15 to Oct
20., still the work is heaviest in the beginning.

I suppose you know almost as much about the Refuge sta-
tion at Chandelier as I do mother but it is what I mainly think
about. As to personal matters, after the season is over I want to
go to Fla - by Mobile & have some teeth pulled & see after the
little grove. I will have paid $26.00, by Sept. 1st & $4.00 I
borrowed from Hill. This would finish payment but for $41.
spent for fertilizers & some for prunning & Cow-peat. How-
ever all will be paid by Oct 1st, & I can pay back the $4.00
in a little while. I want to put out 10 8 acres more,
(that were put in peas this year) in oranges & lemons &
to get up 4 acres ready for peas next. summer, that
is about all the cleared land except the 2 1/2 acres in game
on the place. If I can - the travelling expenses came in heavily just
now- I will come on then to Va: although I would have but a
short time to stay. still a short stay will be worth a great
deal to me.

As to refusing my [?] there was no chance to make
a question of it. It was all one sided. It had been wrong,
unprofitable & unpleasant to have taken it. Although there sh'd
I have gave?
